questions.question:
Question 1: While assessing the Apgar score of the newborns, you would assess and score all of the 
following except:
questions.explanation:
Respiratory effort, not rate is a component of Apgar score. The Apgar score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn's condition using the 5 
parameters explained below. It is performed at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth. • Color (A, appearance) • Heart rate (P, pulse) • Response to a catheter in nostril (G, grimace) • Muscle tone (A, activity) • Respiratory effort (R) Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 
1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the 60 
Sold by @itachibot baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

questions.question:
Question 2: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth, is found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping 
respiration. Heart rate is 60 beats/min, and shows minimal response to stimulation with 
some flexion of extremities. The Apgar score for this newborn is
questions.explanation:
The Apgar score in this baby is 4. It is calculated as: Appearance: blue - score 0 Pulse: <100 beats/min - score 1 Grimace: with minimal response to stimulation - score 1 Activity: some flexion of the extremities - score 1 Respiratory effort: irregular - score 1 The total score is 4. Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 
1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the 
baby is responding to resuscitative efforts. Causes for low Apgar score are: • Fetal distress • Prematurity • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate • Acute cerebral trauma • Precipitous delivery • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia) • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis • Haemorrhage- hypovolemia False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels. A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition. An infant with a score 
of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant 
should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes. 61 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: Where would you attach the oxygen inlet in the instrument given below? 56 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask. It is used in neonatal resuscitation; it 
inflates automatically, without a compressed gas source. • Marking 1 is the pressure release valve. • Marking 2 is the 360-degree swivel. • Marking 3 is the oxygen inlet. • Marking 4 is the air inlet. The parts of the self-inflating bag and mask are labeled in the image below: 62 
Sold by @itachibot Absolute contraindication for using the bag and mask ventilation is congenital diaphragmatic 
hernia

questions.question:
Question 4: A 35-week neonate with grade 2 meconium-stained amniotic fluid is delivered by emergency 
LSCS. There is no spontaneous cry and the baby is unresponsive to tactile stimulation also. As 
the intern assisting in resuscitation, what is the order of suctioning that you will follow?
questions.explanation:
During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth is suctioned first and then the nares, in order 
to decrease the risk of aspiration. A 12 or 14 French suction catheter is used, with the suction 
pressure kept between 80-100 mmHg. Routine suctioning of the trachea during neonatal resuscitation is not recommended. 
The suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided if not indicated specifically. It may 
produce a vagal response - apnea and/or bradycardia due to stimulation of the nerve in the 
posterior pharynx.

questions.question:
Question 5: What is the ideal ratio of compression to ventilation that you would use in the resuscitation of 
a newborn?
questions.explanation:
The ratio of compressions to ventilation in the resuscitation of the newborn is 3:1 (90 
compressions: 30 breaths in one minute). A 3:1 compression-to-ventilation ratio is used for neonatal resuscitation where compromise of gas 
exchange is nearly always the primary cause of the cardiovascular collapse. Chest compressions are indicated if the heart rate is below 60/min even after 30 seconds of 
positive pressure ventilation. Once the HR is 60/min or more, chest compressions should be 
discontinued.

questions.question:
Question 6: A neonate with suspected birth asphyxia is intubated in the labor room after bag and mask 
ventilation did not yield successful results. All of the following parameters would indicate 
successful ventilation except
questions.explanation:
63 
Sold by @itachibot End-tidal CO2 should be present (EtCO2 should not be zero). This is an important sign of 
successful ventilation. Successful ventilation is signified by the following: • Adequate chest rise • Symmetric breath sounds • Improved pink color • Heart rate > 100 beats/min • Spontaneous respirations • Presence of end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2 should not be zero) • Improved tone

questions.question:
Question 7: A panicked primigravida, at 38 weeks of gestation, rushes to the ER at 3 am as she had not 
appreciated any fetal movements since 10 pm. She is taken up for an emergency c-section in 
view of fetal distress. Following delivery, the infant was cyanotic and apneic. What is the 
preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation?
questions.explanation:
Room air is the preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation in term infants. Resuscitation with room air in term infants is as effective as using 100% oxygen. By using room 
air, we may reduce the risk of hyperoxia which is associated with decreased cerebral blood flow 
and generation of oxygen free radicals. If the neonate does not achieve normal oxygen saturation levels within 90 seconds, increased 
concentrations of oxygen are administered until normal saturation levels are achieved. If pulmonary hypertension is suspected (meconium aspiration, diaphragmatic hernia), one may 
consider 100% oxygen as the initial gas for resuscitation. Resuscitation of most preterm infants 
can be initiated with a slightly higher fraction of inspired oxygen (21–30%). 64 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: During neonatal resuscitation, when would you consider administering IV adrenaline?

options.a: Heart rate < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
options.b: Heart rate < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
options.c: Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation.
options.d: Severe respiratory depression, and failure to respond to positive-pressure ventilation with bag

questions.explanation:
If the heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilation, 
consider administering epinephrine in neonatal resuscitation. Note: Umbilical venous catheter is the preferred method of obtaining emergency vascular access 
in the delivery room.

questions.question:
Question 9: 58 
Sold by @itachibot A 34-year-old lady is taken up for an emergency C-section due to meconium-stained amniotic 
fluid. The neonate does not cry after tactile stimulation and the heart rate is 60 beats/min. In 
order to determine the course of resuscitation, you assess if the baby is vigorous. For this, you 
would consider all of the following parameters except:
questions.explanation:
Color is not a parameter considered to determine if the child is vigorous. Vigorous babies have (HRT): 65 
Sold by @itachibot • Heart rate of >100, • Respiratory effort: good • Tone: good If the infant is vigorous with good respiratory effort and a heart rate >100 beats/min; the mouth 
and nose may be suctioned with a bulb or suction catheter if needed. A newborn is defined as 
non-vigorous if any of the above three signs are absent. Resuscitation of non-vigorous newborns with meconium-stained amniotic fluid includes 
positive-pressure ventilation and in severe cases, endotracheal intubation and chest compressions. Note: Even for non-vigorous infants, endotracheal intubation to aspirate meconium is not 
recommended anymore.

questions.question:
Question 10: A term primiparous lady with moderate mitral stenosis received 2 doses of meperidine, 2 
hours before delivery. She delivers a female baby vaginally, but the baby is apneic at birth. 
What is the most important immediate management of the newborn in this case?

options.c: Administer naloxone in the endotracheal tube

questions.explanation:
The most important immediate management is to maintain adequate ventilation via bag and 
mask, because the baby is apneic. Meperidine is a narcotic and the administration of narcotics such as opioids or barbiturates, to 
the mother shortly before delivery (within 4 hours prior) result in narcosis and respiratory 
depression in the newborn. In these babies, naloxone hydrochloride is given while adequate ventilation (bag and mask) is 
maintained. Breathing in the depressed infant should be maintained until a response to naloxone 
is noted. Naloxone hydrochloride, 0.1 mg/kg, can be given intravenously or intramuscularly.

questions.question:
Question 11: Antenatal imaging in an infant delivered late preterm, showed severe congenital 
diaphragmatic hernia with tracheal occlusion. An airway is secured before the placenta is 
removed from the circulation. What is this procedure called?
questions.explanation:
Ex-utero intrapartum treatment procedure (EXIT) is a procedure by which the airway is secured 
before the infant is separated from the placenta. It allows time to secure the airway in an infant known to have airway obstruction due to various 
causes, including laryngeal atresia or stenosis, teratomas, hygromas, and oral tumors before the 
infant is separated from the placenta. Uteroplacental gas exchange is maintained throughout the 
procedure. Option A: BiPAP machines provide positive airway pressure during exhalation and additional 
positive pressure during inspiration. It allows for adjusting of inspiratory and expiratory 
pressures. The additional pressures augment tidal volume and improve alveolar ventilation. 
Children with neuromuscular weakness and intrathoracic airway obstruction benefit from this. Option C: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a form of cardiopulmonary bypass 
that augments systemic perfusion and provides gas exchange. This may be helpful to prevent and 
treat hypoxia and respiratory acidosis and decrease the work of breathing in ARDS, central apnea, 
refractory shock, severe sepsis, pulmonary hypertension, etc. 66 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: CPAP is provided via a high-flow nasal cannula, with a gas flow of 4-16 L/min. It is used 
in diseases with mildly decreased lung compliance, and low functional residual capacity.

questions.question:
Question 12: A newborn baby has respiratory distress in the delivery room. Attempts to pass a nasogastric 
tube through both the nares are unsuccessful. Genital and ear abnormalities are also noted on 
the preliminary examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Inability to pass the nasogastric tube through both the nares along with the presence of 
respiratory distress, suggests choanal atresia. The presence of ear and genital anomalies along 
with choanal atresia suggests the diagnosis of CHARGE syndrome. It consists of • Coloboma of the eye • Heart anomaly • Choanal Atresia • Retardation • Genital anomalies • Ear anomalies VATER syndrome: Vertebral defects, imperforate anus, tracheoesophageal fistula, as well as radial 
and renal dysplasia. Potter's sequence: Renal agenesis, oligohydramnios, and pulmonary hypoplasia Pierre– Robin syndrome: Micrognathia, retrognathia, and glossoptosis. 67 
Sold by @itachibot Developmental Milestones
